MainClaim.text: "Shifting focus to Mendelssohn’s conception of enlightenment has the effect of acknowledging the importance of diverse forms of historically female intellectuality and sociality

Claim1.text: "Mendelssohn’s conception of enlightenment is inclusive of diverse forms of historically female intellectuality and sociality."

Claim2.text: "The women considered above did not content themselves with implementing Mendelssohn’s views but instead actively and critically engaged with them

Claim3.text: "The conception of enlightenment framed by Mendelssohn has a distinctively inclusive character."

Claim4.text: "Mendelssohn’s conception of enlightenment has been neglected by historians of philosophy and of the Enlightenment."

Claim5.text: "Mendelssohn’s essay on enlightenment emphasizes the importance of culture for enlightenment."

Claim6.text: "Holst appropriates the core distinctions in Mendelssohn’s account to unlock the emancipatory potential of this conception of enlightenment for women."

Claim7.text: "Reimarus’ views on the advance of enlightenment are to be distinguished from Mendelssohn’s more concessive approach."

Claim11.text: "Mendelssohn’s position on the advance of enlightenment is to be situated within the context of his Jerusalem and the strict exclusion of the state (and religion) from authority over matters of conscience."

Claim12.text: "Reimarus’ activity in the Fragment controversy illustrates her cautious but persistent advancement of enlightenment."
